title: Which Slavic country is the richest? - Quora

response.answer_text: Slovenia. I disagree with the other answers claiming its Czechia. Life quality is noticeably higher in Slovenia. It is true that GDP per capita in Czechia is higher, but that says little about the wealth of the average citizen or the life quality. Slovenia is more prosperous by a descent margin with slightly better services, but at the same time has higher taxes. According to the HDI (Human Developmen Index) Slovenia is ranked higher than Czechia. Slo is on the 24th place, under S. Korea (23rd) and above Spain (25th). Czech Republic is on the 26th place, tied with France. Similarly, and arguably more useful, on the income inequality adjusted HDI (IHDI), Slo is 12th, while Czech is 13th (very close and very impressive ranks). —(The HDI is a measure of human development in a nation (education, life expectancy pay per capita). IHDI is adjusted for income inequality. They are both widely used to rank and understand the development of a nation. The IHDI is younger but provides a unique view of how effectively has a national managed to give all of its citizens, poor or wealthy, a certain level of development.)   Slovenes have an average (before tax) pay of between 1600€ and 1900, whereas the average Czech has a salary (before tax) of 1200 to 1500€. The average salary in Czechia and Slovenia drops to 1000€ for Cz and 1300€ for Slo, after tax. It is also worth mentioning that Slovenia is more expensive. Additionally the average and median wealth per adult in Slovenia is more than double that of Czechia. Median:SLO is 50 000€, CZ is 20 000€. For reference both Slovakia (40 000€) and Poland (22 500€) are also above the Czech Republic. (I can not provide an image so there is a link, at the bottom) Both Cz and Slo are ranked among the top 15 in the Global Peace Index. One year Czechia is on top, the next its Slovenia (currently it is Cz). Slovenia benefits from being much smaller (only 2 million people) than both nations, and thus can provide standards higher than both. Either way, both of these nations are often underestimated because of their past, but in truth, they are both highly developed and High Income Countries (HIC). Even by looking just at GDP per capita, they are both more than double the world average. Both countries were born in the 90s and prior both were strongly socialist and yet in only 30 years they have reached this level of wealth and development. Truly impressive! Regardless of the two countries wealth, I think Prague is more beautiful than Ljubljana. Ljubljana has a very unique and fairytale type of beauty, but Prague is Prague! Ljubljana, Slovenia:   Prague, Czech Republic:   Here are the Global Peace Index rankings:  Comment: I know wiki isnt the perfect source but we are not a dissertation here. Feel free to correct me if I made any big mistakes! :) List of countries by wealth per adult - Wikipedia

Russia. For centuries, Russia has been plundered, fleeced, bilked, ransacked, robbed, pillaged by tsars, noblemen, adventurists, officials, Bolsheviks, capitalists, socialists, businessmen, Swedes, Poles, Tatars, Mongols, French, Germans, Jews, Russians, thieves and mafiosi of every stripe. They have tried to steal everything they could with abundance and unchecked avarice and greed, moving millions of tons of natural resources, gold, silver, diamonds, and stuff overseas becoming filthy rich in the process, generation after generation of thieves, while Russian people have been raped, jailed, murdered, slaughtered by millions, and millions more fled for better lives overseas. But guess what? They still haven’t managed to steal everything - there’s still more left than has been taken away ! There still are millions of great, smart, kind, generous, talented people left. Russia simply must be the richest Slavic country if after centuries of unchecked pillage and mind-boggling self-destruction there is plenty of riches left. The new generation of thieves is doing its upmost to appropriate all the Russia’s riches. Good luck to them - millions have tried before them in vain.  Diamonds  Deforestation  Oil extraction ….converted into ….  Superyachts  Palaces  Private jets

Richest is subjective. Russia, for example, is obviously by far the richest in natural resources, but there are more exacting ways to determine the actual wealth of the people. It's obvious also that Russia's monetary wealth is distributed very unevenly. Exports is revenue. When the dollar value of exports on a per capita basis is considered, Russia's 141 million people find themselves even poorer than Romanians, $2,490 vs $3,031. A quick look at the Slavik peoples probably puts the Slovenians at the top, at $15,285 in export value per capita, followed closely by Slovakia at $14,851, and Czechia at $13,530. Those three Slavic countries’ people are on a par with some Western Europeans (not including UK at $6,470) some of whom are well into the double digits (Ireland at $42,441, Switzerland at $37,000, Netherlands at $32,152, Belgium and Luxembourg over $25,000, etc) and countries with very large populations find themselves with much lower numbers. China's 1.4 billion people export $1,786 of product per capita, the U.S.’s 330 million people export $4,668 of product per capita, and so on. It's yet another statistic, and statistics tell a story.

By the total amount of resourses and by the number of ultra rich people - Russia. However Russia is far behind by average life standards of “normal” “working class” people. The wealthies are: Slovenia Chechia Poland Slovakia Croatia The rest of Slavic countries are still struggling and some are in desperate poverty (the “rest” are: Bulgaria, Serbia, Macedonia, Ukraine, Belarus, Bosnia, Montenegro). Please note, in my TOP 5 only Slavic countries of Eastern Europe are included. If we include non-Slavic, the third would be Estonia, the fourth Lithuania and the sixth Hungary. Croatia then would be the seventh, sharing that place with Latvia. I mashed up average “wealth” indicators as: minimal wage, average wage, human development index, life cost, gini coefficient, unemployment rate, GDP per capita (PPP) and automobiles per 1000 people.

Richest in which ways, my friend? I think you will have to define it. Economy? No need to doubt, Russia is on topLife expectancy? Welcome to Poland and Czech RepublicRoses? Funny, welcome to BulgariaTolerance? Bosnia and Poland are on topGDP per/capita? Poland, Slovakia, Czech Republic and CroatiaMilitary experience? Serbia, Poland, Russia, BulgariaNatural? Croatia, Bulgaria, Russia and UkraineSounds fun. I like this question

If we talk about GDP per capita the richest Slavic country is Czech Republic , followed by Slovenia and Slovakia (as shown by Denis Havlik) . Otherwise in terms of total wealth it’s Russia . For HDI it is Slovenia (22th) or around .  On the image you can clearly see Czech Republic being in lead . In terms of which is the poorest Slavic country , it’s Ukraine being 2nd poorest in Europe (Moldova being the poorest state in the whole continent) .

Well, this is not very important because Slavic is mainly language group, but clearly Czechia and Slovenia, some metrics are better in Czechia other in Slovenia. So they are much/less same… followed by Slovakia and Poland. I am quite “shocked” by some answers, absolutely out of topic. Btw, GDP nominal? Really? So, welcome prosperous and rich India, Brasil or México! (Without any insult), but It's the elementary wrong understanding of the hard data…

Russia, for sure. Maybe not if you look at GDP per capita, but… One, it’s a huge and politically very influential and powerful country and two, it can cause quite big problems to other Slavic countries if they stop trading with them (and to the rest of the world). And other things, but for now this. And don’t forget, Russia has access to gas and oil! If we look per capita then as Denis Havlik wrote: Czech Republic, followed by Slovenia and then others.

In per capita terms, it's the Czech republic, followed by Slovenia and Slovakia. From List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita - Wikipedia  In terms of the total wealth, it's Russia. Russia is a very big country… From List of countries by GDP (PPP) - Wikipedia
Czechia, if you are speaking based on GDP per capita. With the runner uppers being Slovenia and Slovakia  Castle in Czechia Thank you!
Slovenia and Czechia are about a match. The third formerly socialist country to be in this group is NOT a “Slavic language majority one”, i.e. Estonia.
